subject: Re: Problems running JUnit
msgSnippet: Thanx Lasse, But I have red somewhere that @Test methods (in my case, the met method) isn t supposed to be instrumented with parameters and should not return
messageBody:
Thanx Lasse,
But I have red somewhere that @Test methods (in my case, the met
method) isn't supposed to be instrumented with parameters and should
not return values. This wont work in JUnit at all?
Maybe I am wrong here....

I get error messages here, which say that void method is not allowed
here (assertequals...)..


Also I have to include some importing at the top of the program?
Like this:


import java.lang.annotation.Annotation;
//import junit.framework.Test;
import junit.framework.TestCase;
import junit.framework.TestSuite;
import static org.junit.Assert.*;
import org.junit.*;
import java.util.*;

public class X {
public int met (int number) {
int num = number;
if (num > 1)
return num*2;
else{
return 666;
}
}
}


or maybe more correct in this file:


import java.lang.annotation.Annotation;
import junit.framework.Test;
import junit.framework.TestCase;
import junit.framework.TestSuite;
import static org.junit.Assert.*;

public class TestX {
@Test
public void numbersAboveOneShouldGetDoubled() throws
Exception {
assertEquals(4, new X().met(2));
assertEquals(6, new X().met(3));
assertEquals(8, new X().met(4));
}

@Test
public void numbersEqualOrBelowOneShouldYield666() throws
Exception {
assertEquals(666, new X().met(1));
assertEquals(666, new X().met(0));
assertEquals(666, new X().met(-4));
}
}


Again Thanx a lot.

Magnus








--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Lasse Koskela" <lasse.koskela@...>
wrote:
>
> Hi Magnus,
>
> On 10/22/06, t703093 <t703093@...> wrote:
> > There was 1 failure:
> > 1) TestX
> > java.lang.Exception: No runnable metods
> > at
org.junit.internal.runners.TestClassMethodsRunner.testAborted
> > (TestClassMethodsRunner.java:42)
> > at.....
> >
> > I assume my classes (both the class X and TestX) must be
instrumented
> > in some way to make this work? I am totally new to JUnit, so maybe
> > You clould show me how to instrument those classes?
> >
> > Here they are:
> >
> > public class TestX {
> > public static void main (String args[]){
> > X y = new X();
> > System.out.println(y.met(1));
> > }
> > }
> >
> > ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
> >
> > public class X {
> > public int met (int number) {
> > int num = number;
> > if (num > 1)
> > return num*2;
> > else{
> > return 666;
> > }
> > }
> > }
> >
> > ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
> >
> > maybe I shall put in @Test somewhere in the code above?
>
> Yes, your test class currently doesn't have any test methods. A test
> method is a "@Test public void" (non-static), can be named as you
> wish, and can throw any exception. For example:
>
> public class TestX {
> @Test
> public void numbersAboveOneShouldGetDoubled() throws Exception {
> assertEquals(4, new X().met(2));
> assertEquals(6, new X().met(3));
> assertEquals(8, new X().met(4));
> }
>
> @Test
> public void numbersEqualOrBelowOneShouldYield666() throws
Exception {
> assertEquals(666, new X().met(1));
> assertEquals(666, new X().met(0));
> assertEquals(666, new X().met(-4));
> }
> }
>
>
> On 10/22/06, t703093 <t703093@...> wrote:
> > Both files are placed in a different directory then JUnit
directory?
> > Is that a problem?
>
> That's not a problem. Directories don't matter as long as all the
> compiled .class files are in the class path while running JUnit.
> Whether they're all in one directory tree, in two directory trees,
in
> one directory and three .jar files, doesn't matter.
>
>
> Lasse
>
